question: A simple pendulum has a period of 2.0 seconds. If the length of the pendulum is doubled, what will be the new period of the pendulum?
solution: The period of a simple pendulum is given by the formula T = 2π√(L/g), where T is the period, L is the length of the pendulum, and g is the acceleration due to gravity. If the length of the pendulum is doubled, the new length will be 2L. Substituting this into the formula, we get: T_new = 2π√(2L/g) = 2π√(2)√(L/g). The original period was T = 2π√(L/g), so T_new = √2 * T. Therefore, if the original period was 2.0 seconds, the new period will be 2.0 * √2 ≈ 2.8 seconds.
